text: Torch.jl does zero copy array interchange and works to transfer data between Flux and torch. We wrap things in a tensor array type

elements.text: Torch.jl does zero copy array interchange and works to transfer data between Flux and torch. We wrap things in a tensor array type

text: That’s for models written in Flux and run in libtorch though, right?

elements.text: That’s for models written in Flux and run in libtorch though, right?

text: No. We have all of libtorch wrapped, but I'll admit that we need to add interfaces for more of the Julia API.

elements.text: No. We have all of libtorch wrapped, but I'll admit that we need to add interfaces for more of the Julia API.

text: I mean you can’t run a model written in .py file?

elements.text: I mean you can’t run a model written in .py file?

text:
Libtorch isn't python based. There's no python involved here. You can use pycall for python if you so wish.

But you can definitely use/ load/ mess with a model saved with python and pytorch if that's what you're asking.

elements.text:

But you can definitely use/ load/ mess with a model saved with python and pytorch if that's what you're asking.

text: Load a pytorch model with torch.jl or PyCall? Yeah that’s basically what I’m asking. My impression of Torch.jl was that it mapped ops like conv applied to the tensor array type to their respective ATen ops.
